title: Resultism Guide v1.0
caption: New Project Management Methodology
description:
Resultism Guide v1.0 (2025)

Only. Results. Matter.

 

Overview

Resultism™ is a clearly defined workflow methodology that, if properly followed, allows teams to get any kind of work done without burnout, micromanagement, and passive aggression. By leveraging the advantages and disadvantages of real-life working environments, Resultism aims to drive the only thing that truly matters at work: results. Although seemingly prescriptive, Resultism outlines and enforces the absolute necessary behaviors for achieving results without overstepping professional and personal boundaries. Being purposefully minimalistic, the methodology can be used in combination with other methodologies, principles, and frameworks, but the possible interference from the additional elements not mentioned in this guide should not be attributed to Resultism. Resultism does not aim to reform or reinvent the way a work is done. Resultism does not aim to synchronize the team or make it “feel like a family.” Resultism’s one and only purpose is for the team to achieve the best possible results.

Key features

  1. Autonomy. Resultism empowers self-management as long as the expected results are delivered. However, if the results cannot be delivered, direct management is always an option.
  2. Inclusion. Traditional Agile methodologies stem mostly from IT, thus focusing on addressing uncertainty and delivering features or iterations of the final product. Resultism focuses on delivering results at scale, both in IT and non-IT industries, where work can be both certain and uncertain, feature-based or service-based. Thus, Resultism excels at managing even mundane repetitive work, while maintaining great flexibility to address uncertainty of creative and/or complex work.
  3. Scalability. Resultism can be easily implemented at any scale because it is non-restrictive in terms of structure or workflow, while being very clearly defined in terms of expected outcomes of each element of the workflow. Thus, it is perfect for scaling, enhancing, merging, and expanding teams and businesses of any type.
  4. Integration. Resultism can easily integrate and cooperate with other working styles, including, but not limited to Agile, Scrum, XP, Kanban, and Waterfall. Both within the team and externally with teams using other frameworks. That is achieved by focusing on results, expectations, and outcomes rather than ways of communication or workstyles.
  5. Flexibility. As opposed to Agile, Scrum, Kanban and other methodologies where a work backlog is created and given to the team, Resultism creates a set of results required from the Workers. As long as the expected results are clear and can be achieved by a certain time, the requirements can be provided in any format.
  6. Simplicity. While other methodologies require fine-tuning and multiple adjacent practices and tools to work, this guide already includes everything you need to make it work. For example, it is not a secret that Scrum is often used with Kanban to visualize the work, while Kanban itself has multiple add-ons like Item Aging, WIP Limit, Throughput, etc. Those additional practices were carefully filtered and included in this guide for your convenience.
  7. Responsibility. Since the expected results have to be clearly outlined and achieved, Resultism naturally holds each party accountable. The methodology was created with the purpose to introduce and constantly enforce freedom and self-management in balance with responsibility, as there are no other binding or distracting elements (like meetings or “ceremonies”) apart from Results.

Background

First of all, Resultism™ has no connection with ROWE (Results Only Working Environment), which I respect and am familiar with nonetheless. Resultism stems from my understanding of multiple methodologies and frameworks coupled with extensive real work experience as a project manager, which can often be the complete opposite of what the methodologies describe. Having worked in South Korea, which is notorious for its oppressive and highly stressful working environment, with little to no ability to implement Agile, I devised and implemented the working principles outlined in this guide in my work to achieve the needed results and maintain a healthy lifestyle, both mentally and physically.

While I acknowledge that other methodologies can achieve wonderful results and create amazing cultures, I also realize that oftentimes it is impossible to implement them before it is too late. Sometimes, to make existing methodologies and frameworks effective, roles have to be reassigned, people have to be reeducated, and some complicated tools have to be used. Instead of taking on those gargantuan tasks, Resultism singles out the behaviors that contribute to results, creating a pathway to success that can be used as a reference by anyone regardless of seniority or line of work.

To make an analogy, imagine that you have to get to the sea (results) while going down a river (workflow) with multiple sub-streams (excessive communication, endless meetings, micromanagement, scope creep, etc.). Resultism aims to find the main trajectory that leads to the sea, while making the sub-streams apparent and giving you the choice on what to do about them.

Rules

  1. Only. Results. Matter.
  2. Everything else comes from and after results.
  3. Where, when, and how anyone works is no one’s business if the work is done.
  4. Less is more. 
  5. If it can be an email, it should be one.
  6. Work is work. The rest is the rest.
  7. If a team uses Resultism™, its members can use this guide as the ultimate reference to settle disputes.
  8. No “walk-in” or “on-foot” requests. 
  9. All work is managed using appropriate programs.
  10. No status updates - refer to the Board.
  11. No meetings unless absolutely necessary.

Artifacts & Terms

  1. The Board

    1. Kanban board - physical or digital.
    2. Accessible to anyone, but managed by Results Manager and Workers, except for Finish Line, which is Results Driver’s responsibility.
    3. Provides transparency and becomes the Single Source of Truth for the team and stakeholders.
    4. Divided into Swimlanes for each department/role/specialist.
    5. The WIP Limit (Work In Progress Limit - the maximum number of tickets in a single column) is the number of people on the team.

  2. The Finish Line

    1. The set of results that are expected from the entire team and from each swimlane, placed at the rightmost end of the board with the following details:
      1. A brief description of the result - non-technical, actual end result.
        1. For example, “Create a login page for our application.”
        2. A (automated or pre-configured) checklist of criteria that will be used to (in)validate the results.
          1. For example, “1. Login/PW work. 2. Delivered exactly on time. 3. Other buttons like Support are functional. 4. Documentation is ready for client sign-off.”
      2. All the responsible assignees.
        1. There will not be “too many notifications,” as the Finish Line will only have general expected results

  3. Swimlane

    1. A specific team or role, marked by horizontal borders across the Board, limiting their area of work.
      1. Swimlanes can have an additional Swimlane Finish before the general Finish Line.
      2. Swimlane Finish is managed by Results Driver as well.

  4. Ticket

    1. A sub-result that needs to be delivered within a swimlane.
    2. Must include:
      1. A brief description of the result - in any form, including technical tasks.
      2. A (automated or pre-configured) checklist of criteria that will be used to (in)validate the results.
        1. For example, “1. Login/PW work. 2. Delivered exactly on time. 3. Other buttons like Support are functional. 4. Documentation is ready for client sign-off.”
      3. Due date.
      4. Assignment of other teams or parties that require or are affected by the result, including the Inspector.

  5. Neutral Message (NM)

    1. A structured template of communication to be used by everyone on the team.
    2. Aimed to eliminate passive aggression, misunderstandings, and miscommunications.
    3. Regardless of the perceived tone and politeness, it should always be evaluated objectively at face value, as a container for information.
    4. Consists of the following:
      1. Greetings.
      2. Requests in the form of bullet points with the following structure:
        1. What.
        2. By when.
        3. How.
        4. (Optional) Why.
      3. Questions in the form of bullet points. Example:
        1. Question: is it possible to put labels on all of the MR36 with their service periods?
      4. Comments in the form of bullet points. Example:
        1. Comment: would be nice to have cable patching done prior to the IT team's visit, but no pressure.
      5. Goodbyes.

Roles

It is not mandatory to assign the roles to separate individuals. As long as they are properly performed, they can be assigned to as many people as needed.

  1. Results Inspector

    1. Knows the end results that need to be delivered.
    2. Constantly communicates with Results Driver to align on the results expected.
    3. Doesn’t communicate with the rest of the team

  2. Results Driver

    1. Manages the results requirements.
    2. Constantly updates the Finish Line.
    3. Breaks down the expected results for each swimlane and/or role if necessary.
    4. Ensures that all the results are synchronized and detailed.
    5. Configures the necessary checklists and quality criteria for the results.
    6. Configures automations and other tools related to the results.

  3. Results Manager

    1. Ensures that the results are delivered.
    2. Helps the team to deliver acceptable results on time by any means necessary.
    3. The level of responsibility for the results is directly proportional with the level of authority over the project and the team.
    4. Creates and maintains a process map, which outlines only the necessary elements and parties to achieve results.
    5. Maintains comprehensive project documentation.
    6. Measures necessary work KPIs and other measurements that will help align future expectations regarding results and timelines.

  4. Worker

    1. Does the work.
    2. Workers manage their own work as long as the needed results are achieved, without external interference.
    3. Request help from Results Manager if necessary (only by creating a Ticket).
